Well, this was a double challenge. I really enjoyed the cryptic crossword. I did not enjoy the part about trying to find where the blog had been hidden. I still don't know what I did right so that I finally got here. I kept clicking on the thing that said "Variety: Cryptic Crossword" and winding up in the middle of last week.

Overall, a wonderful puzzle. Favorites: EDITH WHARTON, ROWDINESS, NO SWEAT, SLOE GIN, STRAIGHTEN, PROMETHEUS. And some others. I loved a lot of them. Least favorites: LYNDON (least favorite because it was so hard for me, not because there was anything wrong with it), REDIG (just an ugly word).

Discovery: While working on 19D, I noticed that "U.N. that" is an anagram of U THANT. Didn't help getting the entry, though. Quite the opposite.

Hand up for Deb's thoughts about SWORDS.

I cannot believe how long I tried to find a way to put SPECKLE in at 5A and figure out a S?W? bird.

Thanks for all the fun, all. And someone please ask the techies not to make it so hard to find the blog.

My takeaway is that doctors don't talk about sex with either teens or the elderly, when they should be. If they did, seniors would be getting tested for STDs and undergo regular colonoscopies, as appropriate.

Dr. Emanuel is right. AARP, the AMA, condom makers, the CDC, HHS, and state health departments all should get behind a coordinated information campaign nationwide, and especially in senior communities. Certain STDs are making a comeback in strain-resistant form and 6% of seniors having unprotected sex is an unacceptable state of affairs.

As far as more graphs, I do know that since the start of the Great Recessions, more older Americans are rooming together due to lower disposable income and higher cost of renting. It may be more difficult to home in on exactly where seniors are more vulnerable. We do know, however, that they make use of their medical benefits. That is where it is a must that doctors make it a part of their protocol to talk to patients about safe sex.

I think the problem wasn't so much that Target was storing customer data long-term as that the hackers were capturing the data as it entered the point-of-sale computer - as cards were swiped and PINs entered.  Then the hackers moved it to a Target server which they had hijacked for the purpose of storing it temporarily.

As a good faith gesture Target should give a 5% discount when using cash at their stores. It may bring back customers like me who got spooked by the data breach-- I haven't shopped there since the news broke, and I used to go three or four times a month.
One thing for sure, I am never using a credit card or debit card at Target again. They've lost my trust permanently.

While I actually agree with most of what you said, I don't think that "Phil knew that he was gay from the start" is actually accurate. He *did* admit that he had had a "homosexual experience" -- but that is NOT the same as admitting he "was gay." For many gay men then (and now, unfortunately), they learned from their parents and their society that homosexuality was a condition, a psychiatric disorder, and that while they might have had experiences it was not something that enough hard psychological work or "therapy" couldn't solve. In other words: it was an illness that could be cured, not an unchangeable condition.

Everyone is hurt in this situation, but I think it's too flippant to say that "whoops, Phil knew he was a gay man and hid it all these years." It's incredibly difficult even now for many gay individuals to come out under the pressures of society and I can't even imagine what it must have been like in the 1960s.

Hi NYCVet,

While I don't believe in exploitation of animals or humans and don't agree with using animals for profit, I appreciate your thoughtful comment. The main concern seems to be the future of the horses when removed from New York.

I am conflicted on the carriage horse issue, in large part because I'm not convinced that a ban would improve the quality of life of the current carriage horses. There is no guarantee of idyllic, life-long retirement for these horses, and there's reason to think that an abrupt removal from their current environment, activity, and companions would be highly stressful.
While I object to some of the industry's current practices, in many ways the horses are very well cared-for and lead good lives. I say this based on time that I have spent at Clinton Stables as well as my veterinary training. Clinton Stables is well worth a visit: it is well-ventilated and airy, dry, and well-lit; the stalls are large and the horses are quiet and content.
The primary issue that concerns me is the presence of horses in traffic. I think that many minds would be put at ease were there a dedicated horse lane going to and from the stables and Central Park, and if carriage rides were limited to within Central Park. From my conversations with those in the carriage horse industry, I believe that the industry would welcome such changes. If Teddy could talk, he might ask for reform, rather than either a ban or the status quo.
I believe that open conversation among all parties, with inclusion of experts in equine health and behavior, is the only way to find a path forward that respects and values the horses as well as the humans involved.

Here in rural Maine, we have cell phone reception in exactly one place--the window seat in the bay window at the furthest-East end of the house. If we wanted to hear a cell phone caller clearly, we'd have to drive one mile.

This is not unique in rural areas--and rural people are just as important as city people. We'll keep our land line until some money-hungry technocrat severs it.
